alt="Small Business Advocacy Council president Elliot Richardson sits behind a desk" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1c591e9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2Fea%2F9a229bc94304961bd104b5c9ca9d%2Fsbac-bizlicensefees-260222-04.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/371f00c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2Fea%2F9a229bc94304961bd104b5c9ca9d%2Fsbac-bizlicensefees-260222-04.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1c591e9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+324/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F23%2Fea%2F9a229bc94304961bd104b5c9ca9d%2Fsbac-bizlicensefees-260222-04.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Small Business Advocacy Council president Elliot Richardson</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“While there was stiff opposition to raising these fees, doing it during the budget process made it difficult for this issue to gain traction given the other budgetary battles being fought,” he said.</p><p>The higher fees took effect weeks after Mayor Brandon Johnson in December announced his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2025/12/05/mayor-brandon-johnson-cut-red-tape-small-businesses-entrepreneurs" >“Cut the Tape for Small Business” initiative</a>.</p><p>A steep “increase in fees seems like a lot more red tape to me,” Shurtliff said. “It's prohibitively expensive for small service-based businesses — cleaning, creatives, tutors, home-based businesses — many of whom operate on narrow margins. They are barely making ends meet and can’t absorb a sudden $1,000 upfront cost.”</p><p>Shurtliff said helping her friend apply for a business license was complicated and time-consuming.</p><p>“It’s not easy to figure out how to do everything,” she said. “I can’t believe any small business is able to get off the ground without a ton of help.”</p><p>The higher license fees “incentivizes people to operate without a business license,” Shurtliff said. “Why are we giving so many tax breaks to big businesses and not giving breaks to small businesses?”</p><p>Fees for regulated and limited business licenses hadn’t been changed since 2012, according to a joint statement from the Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection and the Chicago Office of Budget Management.</p><p>“These adjustments help maintain essential city services while supporting long-term financial stability for the city of Chicago,” the departments said.</p><p>The city analyzed business license fees in other big U.S. cities and found those in Chicago were lower than its peers.</p><p>“Some of our peer jurisdictions charge a much higher rate for the same service, better capturing the true cost to deliver that service to the public,” the departments said. “For example, a typical New York City regulated business license fee is $1,440, an example of the inconsistency between what the city of Chicago charges versus peer cities.”</p><p>Richardson said, “We cannot turn back the clock on these fee increases and doubt Chicago politicians will take action to nullify them. They can, however, ensure the additional revenue raised through increased fees and fines are used to improve processes for small businesses.”</p><p>Shurtliff said,<b> </b>“It helps people make a living wage when they can own a business. We want people to be self-sufficient.”</p><p>Licensed businesses “are on the books. They pay taxes,” Shurtliff said. “It’s to all our benefit to make it as easy and cheap as possible to start one.”</p><p>The new fees as of Jan. 1, according to the Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection, include:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-268b5480-0eb9-11f1-8347-4938c4da6a61"><li>Limited business license: $500 for a two-year license, previously $250</li><li>Regulated business license: $1,000 for a two-year license, previously $250</li><li>Hotel license: $1,000 plus $2.20 per room for a two-year license, previously $250 plus $2.20 per room</li><li>Commercial vessel license: $600 for any passenger occupancy limit, previously $350 annual license for commercial passenger vessel (tour boat or water taxi) with 20 or more occupancy and $75 annual license fee for under 20 occupancy</li><li>Shared housing unit registration: $250 per year, previously $125</li><li>Shared housing unit operator license: $500 for a two-year license, previously $250</li><li>Application for Commissioner’s adjustment for shared housing units: $360 per application, previously no fee</li></ul><p>As of Feb. 1, the new license fees include:<br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" id="rte-268b5481-0eb9-11f1-8347-4938c4da6a61"><li>Livery vehicle: $1,200 for a two-year license, previously $500 annual license fee</li><li>Charter/sightseeing vehicle: $1,000 annual fee, previously $500</li><li>Medical carrier vehicle: $600 annual fee, previously $500</li></ul><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2026/01/15/volumes-bookcafe-wicker-park-close" >Volumes Bookcafe in Wicker Park prepares to close</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Amy Yee

entries.title: Frustrated Illinois congressional candidates call super PAC influence 'buying a seat'
entries.summary: <p>Super PACs benefitting cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence and Israel are actively working to influence Illinois congressional races — and candidates in four already competitive and crowded districts aren’t happy.</p><p>They’re likening the super PAC support to buying a seat and dark money bombardment. Others are accusing Democrats of being beholden to interests that will benefit President Donald Trump’s administration — a clearly unpopular issue for Democrats in a primary.</p><p>“It seems like easy pickings for the types of giant corporate interest that wants to come in and spend,” said Reed Showalter, a candidate in the<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-about-illinois-7th-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" > 7th Congressional District</a>. “A few million dollars to buy a seat in Congress is a good deal. And for the rest of everybody who’s playing a grassroots game, that is a very damaging thing.”</p><p>Showalter is one of several candidates speaking out about the influence of super PACs in this primary cycle — in an unprecedented year with four open congressional seats and a Senate seat open in Illinois. </p><p>The American Israel Public Affairs Committee — the powerful pro-Israel organization — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/19/rep-jan-schakowsky-withdrawal-donna-miller-endorsement-2nd-congressional-district-aipac-support" >is playing a role</a> in four congressional races in Illinois — helping to boost Cook County Commissioner Donna Miller in the 2nd; former U.S. Rep. Melissa Bean in the 8th; state Sen. Laura Fine in the 9th; and Chicago City Treasurer Melissa Conyears Ervin in the 7th. United Democracy Project, AIPAC’s affiliated super PAC, has spent more than $753,000 directly to support Conyears Ervin.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-2nd-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" >The 2nd District</a> is especially hit hard by super PAC influence, with Fairshake, a pro-crypto PAC funded primarily by Trump megadonors and business partners Marc Andreessen and Ben Horowitz, targeting State Sen. Robert Peters. Fairshake is spending at least $1 million to run anti-Peters ads. And it’s the third Trump-affiliated super PAC to play a role in the race.</p><p>Andreessen is the founder and general partner of Silicon Valley venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz — and a Trump adviser on tech and business policy — and he gave more than $4.7 million to advance the MAGA agenda in the 2023 and 2024 electoral cycle.</p><p>Affordable Chicago Now!, which is AIPAC-affiliated, is spending money in support of Miller, while the Leading the Future PAC, funded by OpenAI stakeholders, is backing former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. in the race.</p><p>Peters’ campaign says Fairshake is targeting him because he voted for crypto state legislation that imposed new rules on digital asset firms. Peters co-sponsored the measure.</p><p>“I think any time big right wing billionaire donors come into a race, it’s like a jolt,” Peters said.</p><p>Peters said all three entities “are scared of having an effective progressive champion in this seat.”</p><p>“There’s a whole group of really corrupt billionaires who have really close attachment to the Trump administration, who want people who are going to be soft on their issues, and so that means people who are going to be OK with unconditional military aid in [Israel Prime Minister Benjamin] Netanyahu’s war machine," Peters said. "That means people who are going to be OK with the advancement of AI slop and the increase in utility rates. That means people who are OK with the corrupt practices of the crypto bros who have been literally benefiting from the Trump administration and I believe have played a role in Trump’s ability to gain more wealth.”</p><p>Junaid Ahmed, a candidate in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-about-illinois-8th-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" >8th Congressional District,</a> is a progressive endorsed by the Sunrise Movement, who is also railing against the influence of super PACs. He’s frustrated that mailers call Bean an “architect of Obamacare,” and reference a 2010 Chicago Tribune article about her role in Obamacare — though in reality the article discusses how she had not made a decision to sign the measure. Bean ultimately did support Obamacare. </p><p>“That’s the part that dark money is doing here. When a voter sees that kind of bombardment, the shouting from the rooftops, that’s a direct impact,” Ahmed said. “And they’re able to by making ads on any topic that polls well — don’t even bring the word AI, don’t even bring the word AIPAC — just focus on what’s polling well and then bombard the voters, and then buy our races.”</p><p>Showalter, a former attorney for the Federal Trade Commission and U.S. Justice Department counsel, believes publicly funding elections — and ending Citizens United — would make a huge difference in deflating the power of special interests. He credited New York City's program, in which candidates receive public funding that partially matches what they raise, for helping Zohran Mamdani win the mayoral seat. </p><p>"You have a matching program where you raise up to a million dollars and it's matched eight-to-one," Showalter said. "That makes a big difference for people who are candidates who are running in a grassroots publicly supported way, so that you don't have to rely on the millions and millions of dollars that can frankly only be deployed by giant corporate interests."</p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: Four questions for the Bears to answer at this week's NFL Scouting Combine
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> are going to Indiana — for the week, at least.</p><p>While the organization continues to negotiate with politicians from both Illinois and Indiana <br>to try to score the best deal possible for their new stadium site, members of the Bears front office and coaching staff will descend upon the NFL Scouting Combine in Indianapolis.</p><p>Bears coach Ben Johnson and general manager Ryan Poles will meet the media Tuesday just blocks from the Indiana statehouse. At issue won’t be building a stadium, but the next step in what the Bears hope is a Super Bowl contender.</p><p>Here are four things to watch this week:</p><h3>How will the Bears get under the salary cap?</h3><p>The Bears sit $4.1 million above the 2026 salary cap of $303.5 million, per Over the Cap, and have until the first day of the league year next month to get under it.</p><p>Of the many ways for the Bears to get there, the cleanest would be to cut linebacker Tremaine Edmunds and save $15 million. Edmunds ranked second among all NFL linebackers in interceptions last year but the Bears fared well in his four-game injury absence, with backup D’Marco Jackson winning NFC Defensive Player of the Week.</p><p>The Bears could also restructure the contracts of receiver DJ Moore, guard Joe Thuney, defensive tackle Grady Jarrett and others to find extra cap space.</p><p>Speaking of Moore: Johnson and Poles will have a chance Tuesday to make a clear statement about how they value the receiver after he was part of what quarterback Caleb Williams called a miscommunication on the overtime interception against the Rams.</p><p>The Bears have praised Moore’s toughness and intelligence for years, but he’s coming off his worst statistical season with the team and has a $28.5 million salary cap hit in each of the next two years. The Bears won’t cut him, but he could be a trade candidate if they decide to go in a different direction.</p><h3>What to do at No. 25?</h3><p>The last time the Bears arrived at the Combine without either a brand-new head coach or possession of the No. 1 overall draft pick was 2020. This year, then, will be different — picking 25<sup>th</sup> overall, the Bears will be at the mercy of how the draft board breaks in front of them.</p><p>The Bears will need an edge rusher and a defensive tackle regardless of what happens in free agency, as well as someone to play left tackle in place of the injured Ozzy Trapilo. They could look to add a safety — or two — if both Kevin Byard and Jaquan Brisker leave via free agency. The Bears want Byard back. Cornerback could be in play if Nahshon Wright goes elsewhere, too.</p><p>Good news for the Bears: <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/20/bears-nfl-draft-daniel-jeremiah-network-25-overall-defensive-end-left-tackle-good-spot-no-trade-scouting-combine-ryan-poles-ben-johnson" target="_blank" >the draft is considered strong — and deep — at offensive tackle, defensive end and defensive tackle.</a></p><h3>How about a trade?</h3><p>Trade seeds get planted when teams — and agents — gather at the Combine.</p><p>The Bears solved two of their biggest needs in the days after the Combine last year when they traded draft picks for two guards — Joe Thuney and Jonah Jackson — who went on to post exceptional seasons.</p><p>All the NFL will be searching for clarity about whether Raiders star edge rusher Maxx Crosby will be made available in a trade. Bears quarterback Caleb Williams <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/17/bears-raiders-caleb-williams-maxx-crosby-mutual-admiration-podcast-appearance-trade-nfl" target="_blank" >appeared on Crosby’s podcast last week </a>and praised both Johnson and Bears fans.</p><h3>And what about the staff?</h3><h3></h3><p>The Bears lost two offensive assistants to coordinator jobs this offseason. Declan Doyle took the same job with the Ravens, where he will be able to call plays. Running backs coach Eric Bieniemy became the Chiefs’ coordinator, though he won’t call plays.</p><p>The Bears promoted pass-game coordinator Press Taylor to offensive coordinator and hired Eric Studesville as running backs coach. This week will provide Johnson with the first chance to explain why he hired them — and how he plans to continue the momentum on his side of the ball.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Familiar foes line up in Republican primary for chance against Gov. JB Pritzker
entries.summary: <p>There’s no love lost between Gov. JB Pritzker and any of the Republicans vying for a shot against the billionaire Democrat this November.</p><p>Downstate GOP firebrand Darren Bailey lost big to Pritzker four years ago. Video gambling magnate Rick Heidner lost a big chunk of his fortune in regulatory fights with Pritzker’s administration.</p><p>Conservative commentator Ted Dabrowski blames Pritzker for “destroying the quality of life in Illinois,” while DuPage County Sheriff James Mendrick calls the progressive governor “a menace.”</p><p>The four candidates on the Republican primary ballot for governor all say they’re running to tackle familiar complaints against the state’s Democratic power structure — by lowering taxes, reducing crime and generating economic growth — but their campaigns are personal, too.</p><h3>Darren Bailey, former state lawmaker</h3><p>“Six months ago, if you would’ve asked me if I was running for governor, it was a hard no,” said Bailey, a farmer and former state legislator from Xenia in southern Illinois. “But there was just this welling up in our heart that set in, and I knew that we were being called to do this.”</p><p>He stuck to it despite immense personal tragedy in October when a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/10/23/darren-baileys-son-daughter-in-law-2-grandchildren-killed-in-montana-helicopter-crash" target="_blank" ><u>helicopter crash</u></a> claimed the lives of his son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren.</p><p>Leaning on his faith — and with encouragement from President Donald Trump, who <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2022/6/25/23183316/darren-bailey-trump-endorsement-igop-governor-primary-election" target="_blank" ><u>endorsed Bailey’s 2022 gubernatorial campaign</u></a>, but not his failed 2024 primary challenge to U.S. Rep. Mike Bost — he stayed in the race because “I'm fighting for my children and my grandchildren and a better future for everyone in Illinois.”</p><p>Bailey is focusing more on pocketbook issues than the social ones that dominated his 2022 campaign, including protecting gun ownership rights and restricting abortion rights — themes that Pritzker seized on in a backhanded effort to boost Bailey in that GOP primary with ads labeling him “too conservative.” It helped Bailey win <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2022/6/28/23187510/darren-bailey-richard-irvin-pritzker-republican-governors-race-jesse-sullivan" target="_blank" ><u>in a landslide</u></a>, only to get walloped by Pritzker <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2022/11/8/23448412/j-b-pritzker-declares-victory-over-gop-challenger-darren-bailey" target="_blank" ><u>in the general election</u></a> by nearly 13 percentage points.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-b40000" name="image-b40000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c075f3e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4c81bb4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a25fa7a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="State Sen. Darren Bailey, R-Xenia, speaks at an election night rally at the Thelma Keller Convention Center in Effingham after winning the Republican gubernatorial primary election, Tuesday night, June 28, 2022. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a25fa7a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5e7738a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a25fa7a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5447x3057+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F03%2F72664a70442eb670e5f944186ef2%2F2022primary-25.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>State Sen. Darren Bailey, R-Xenia, speaks at an election night rally at the Thelma Keller Convention Center in Effingham after winning the Republican gubernatorial primary election, Tuesday night, June 28, 2022. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Bailey and this year’s primary opponents are against abortion in almost all cases — and quick to point out that they can’t do much about it in deep-blue Illinois, where Democratic supermajorities in the General Assembly have passed numerous protections in the post-Roe v. Wade era.</p><p>Instead, Bailey focuses on a word that Democrats are also emphasizing nationwide heading into midterm elections: affordability.</p><p>“I don't think that people realize the damage that Pritzker [has done] in the last three years, and he's certainly done that, because affordability is front and center today,” Bailey said. “We're hearing it all the time from business and residents, even up here in Chicago — the rents are skyrocketing because of property taxes.”</p><p>“Our approach will be actually doing something about it,” said Bailey, who has proposed a state-level government spending audit akin to the Elon Musk-led DOGE cost-cutting effort that roiled the federal workforce last year.</p><p>Bailey acknowledged he needs to do a better job appealing to voters in the city he famously branded a “<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2022/9/13/23351525/hellhole-republican-darren-bailey-chicago-john-hancock-center-north-side-downstate-pritzker-governor" target="_blank" ><u>hellhole</u></a>.”</p><p>“I want to meet the people, especially in some of the areas where the crime’s higher,” he said. “We thought we were doing that in 2022, but we discovered later that we didn't do it.”</p><p>As for the often-chaotic federal immigration enforcement campaign in Chicago, Bailey said he’d “create a climate where local state and federal law enforcement work together.”</p><p>He also said he’d be open to abating or freezing property taxes for a new football stadium. “We cannot lose the Chicago Bears.”</p><p>Bailey’s lieutenant governor candidate, Cook County Republican Party chair Aaron Del Mar, joined the ticket in an effort to court moderate suburban voters — but Dabrowski says that’s not enough to end Republicans’ eight-year drought from holding statewide office.</p><h3>Ted Dabrowski, conservative pundit</h3><p>“He lost by 35 percentage points up here,” Dabrowski said at his Glenview campaign office. “As much as I supported [Bailey], he couldn't win.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-bd0001" name="image-bd0001"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" alt="Ted Dabrowski, a Republican candidate who is running for the governor of Illinois, speaks to a reporter in his campaign’s office in Glenview, Ill., Wednesday, Jan. 14, 2026. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c4bbd20/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6439x3614+0+340/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F41%2F40%2F42d8d27443b0b7efe1f2bcca19e5%2Fgovernorgop-260213-13.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1a3470d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6439x3614+0+340/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F41%2F40%2F42d8d27443b0b7efe1f2bcca19e5%2Fgovernorgop-260213-13.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c4bbd20/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6439x3614+0+340/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F41%2F40%2F42d8d27443b0b7efe1f2bcca19e5%2Fgovernorgop-260213-13.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Ted Dabrowski, a Republican candidate running in the March primary Illinois governor, discusses his agenda in his campaign’s office in Glenview Jan. 14. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>That’s one reason Dabrowski launched his first run for office after years of punditry with the conservative research and commentary website Wirepoints and the Illinois Policy Institute.</p><p>The son of immigrants from Ecuador and Poland, Dabrowski worked internationally for Citibank before starting a family in the north suburbs and becoming ensconced in the numbers surrounding his home state’s economy, cost of living, crime and population.</p><p>“Every time I looked at the statistics, it was like, ‘Wow, what's wrong? Why are we at the bottom of the list on economic growth or population growth, or the other way, high property taxes, all that stuff,’ and I got engaged,” Dabrowski said. “I didn’t see the legislature actually taking seriously many of these issues, and so finally I said, ‘I can either keep complaining, keep exposing it, or get engaged and try to lead and see if we can change this amazing state back to where it should be.”</p><p>Dabrowski — who dismisses the eight credit-rating upgrades the state has received under Pritzker as the byproducts of massive federal pandemic relief funding — has amassed a well of support that includes conservative megadonor Richard Uihlein, who supported Bailey last time around.</p><p>“We need big change,” said Dabrowski, whose running mate is emergency physician Carrie Mendoza.</p><p>Dabrowski said he’d work to repeal sanctuary policies limiting Illinois law enforcement cooperation with immigration enforcement, accusing Pritzker of “incentivizing these people to go out in the streets and oppose ICE, and that's creating the kind of problems we're seeing.”</p><p>Like Pritzker, Dabrowski says he’s open to state dollars going into infrastructure to help support a new Bears stadium, but opposed to most other potential subsidies.</p><p>Uihlein has put $250,000 behind Dabrowski, who has put $250,000 of his own money into his run and entered the year with the biggest campaign fund in the race with $1.2 million on hand.</p><p>Dabrowski has raised more than $286,000 since October, outpacing the $185,000-plus that Bailey amassed over the same period, while the downstate farmer was burning through much of that war chest. Bailey entered 2026 with about $35,000 on hand.</p><h3>Rick Heidner, the slot machine mogul</h3><p>Vaulting himself near Dabrowski in fundraising is Heidner, the slot machine mogul and real estate entrepreneur who made a late entry into the race last fall with a $1 million campaign contribution.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-780000" name="image-780000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5a4dedb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7bdc4dc/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/55361d4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Rick Heidner, a Republican gubernatorial candidate, speaks during an interview at his Hoffman Estates office." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/55361d4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/585bc2f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/55361d4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5690x3193+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fcd%2Fd8%2Ff6be7dfd44ab9280f18390322b46%2Fgovernorgop-260301-03.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rick Heidner, a Republican gubernatorial candidate, speaks during an interview at his Hoffman Estates office.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Talia Sprague/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>It’s Heidner’s first run for office, but he’s no stranger to politics — or contentious relationships with the government.</p><p>Heidner has given more than $1.4 million to a slew of political candidates and causes over the past three decades, including to many of the Democrats he now is quick to denigrate: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson, Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle — and a $2,500 donation to former Cook County State’s Attorney Kim Foxx that he calls “the most regrettable money I've ever spent in my life.”</p><p>“I've worked through the last 50 years with both sides,” Heidner said. “Every single village, every single town, every [ward] that I've gone to in Chicago, everywhere throughout the state, I've always been able to work with everybody, and I have friends on both sides.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/01/30/rick-heidner-republican-candidate-governor-video-gambling-magnate-ballys-casino-d-and-p-construction-rosemont" >Gov hopeful took money from exec of garbage hauler dogged by mob allegations</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>His business empire includes the Ricky Rockets Fuel Center chain and Gold Rush Gaming, Illinois’ third-largest operator of slot machines outside casinos.</p><p>Heidner said he jumped in the race because none of the other GOP hopefuls “had any chance at all” against Pritzker, who’s unopposed in the March 17 Democratic primary and has pumped a cool $25 million into his reelection campaign.</p><p>Heidner said he’s running to address crime, lower taxes and push for term limits — and that it’s not a personal vendetta against Pritzker, whose administration pulled the plug on a racetrack/casino project that Heidner backed after the Gold Rush founder’s name <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2019/10/11/20910371/rick-heidner-sandoval-warrant-video-gambling" target="_blank" ><u>emerged in federal search warrants</u></a> tied to a sprawling political corruption scandal.</p><p>Heidner, who has never been charged with a crime, said the ordeal cost “about half my wealth,” but “I’m over it.”</p><p>Instead, Heidner rails against crime and legislation signed by Pritzker that eliminated cash bail.</p><p>“I just couldn't stand anymore seeing all the people that are being hurt,” said Heidner, whose running mate is Homer Glen Mayor Christina Neitzke-Troike.</p><p>He claims the state “could have gotten rid of probably 90% of the worst people” if Pritzker had cooperated with federal immigration authorities, and that a new Bears stadium “would be half-built” by now if he were governor.</p><p>Heidner has hosted fundraisers at his Barrington Hills home for Donald Trump Jr., and he shares President Trump’s baseless claims that mail-ballot voter fraud swayed the 2020 presidential election. Asked if President Joe Biden won: “Absolutely not,” Heidner said. “It was insane to me. I couldn’t believe it.”</p><p>Experts have found no credible evidence of widespread voter fraud.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-0f0000" name="image-0f0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5b7e035/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f202d17/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2d2591/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="DuPage County Sheriff James Mendrick, Republican candidate for Illinois governor, speaks with reporters at the Illinois State Fair in Springfield on Aug. 14, 2025. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2d2591/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/78c6eac/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d2d2591/2147483647/strip/true/crop/7372x4137+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F94%2Fd9%2Fdd09c5b840caa6f2e726ad319a1e%2Frepublicanday-081525-21.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>DuPage County Sheriff James Mendrick, Republican candidate for Illinois governor, speaks with reporters at the Illinois State Fair in Springfield on Aug. 14, 2025. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>James Mendrick, DuPage County’s top cop</h3><p>Mendrick, in his second term as sheriff of Illinois’ second largest county, says he’s “not just a police chief.”</p><p>“I run a $70 million operation. I’ve never been a dollar over budget,” while Pritzker “has taxed us into the Stone Age,” said Mendrick, who refused to enforce the assault weapon ban the governor signed in 2023.</p><p>“I'm about law and order. I disagreed with JB Pritzker on all of his stances that he had with COVID, with [the Second Amendment], the SAFE-T Act, the sanctuary state [policies]. The guy, to me, is a menace. I'm his next-door neighbor, and I've had to deal with the repercussions of the big mistakes that JB Pritzker’s made in DuPage County,” Mendrick said.</p><p>He supports coordinating “with ICE to remove criminal migrants from jails before they are released,” and he told the <a class="Link" href="https://www.dailyherald.com/20260204/illinois-state-politics/all-of-us-want-them-to-stay-gop-governor-candidates-opine-on-bears-threats-to-go-hoosier/" target="_blank" ><u>Daily Herald</u></a> he wouldn’t support state help for a Bears stadium without the team first “laying out a comprehensive plan.”</p><p>Mendrick’s, running with author and Army veteran Robert Renteria, entered the year with about $33,000 in his campaign fund.</p><p>“I know how to maneuver through government,” Mendrick said. “Public safety touches every facet of government, so I already know all the players, I've been in all the tangles for all the years — JB Pritzker got elected at the same time as I did.”</p>
entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: 1 dead, 1hurt in 2-vehicle wreck on Dan Ryan in Chatham
entries.summary: <p>One person died and another was injured after a two-vehicle crash late Sunday on the inbound Dan Ryan Expressway at 87th Street. </p><p>The crash happened around 11:30 p.m., leaving two passengers rushed to area hospitals where one of them was pronounced dead, state police said.</p><p>Lanes were temporarily closed for a crash investigation but have since reopened, officials said. </p><p>No further information was immediately given by police. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: 2 women killed in predawn Northlake fire
entries.summary: <p>Two women were killed in a fire early Monday in west suburban Northlake. </p><p>Multiple fire agencies and Northlake police responded to a structure fire around 1:25 a.m. at 74 West Drive, Northlake police said. </p><p>The two women who died in the fire were sisters-in-law, Northlake Police Chief Ken Beres told reporters early Monday. </p><p>Firefighters on the second floor needed to be rescued while trying to extinguish the blaze, Beres said. No injuries to fire personnel were reported. </p><p>The cause of the fire was still under investigation. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Muere 'El Mencho', líder del Cártel Jalisco Nueva Generación que abastece el comercio de cocaína en Estados Unidos
entries.summary: <p>CIUDAD DE MÉXICO — El ejército mexicano mató al líder del <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/8/15/18338774/with-el-chapo-in-jail-dea-and-mexico-focus-on-other-cartels-with-chicago-ties" target="_blank" >Cártel Jalisco Nueva Generación,</a><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2018/10/16/18452115/feds-up-reward-for-kingpin-el-mencho-to-10m-get-win-in-cartel-cash-case-here" target="_blank" > Nemesio Rubén Oseguera Cervantes, conocido como “El Mencho”,</a> en una operación realizada el domingo.</p><p>La Administración de Control de Drogas (DEA) considera que el cártel de Jalisco es tan poderoso como el Cártel de Sinaloa, que adquirió prominencia bajo el liderazgo de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/el-chapo" target="_blank" >Joaquín “El Chapo” Guzmán Loera,</a> con presencia en los 50 estados de Estados Unidos, donde distribuye toneladas de drogas.</p><p>Es uno de los principales proveedores de cocaína para Chicago y el resto de los Estados Unidos, según la <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/08/08/sinaloa-el-chapo-secret-cocaine-dea-lab-tests-flood-cocaine-cartels" target="_blank" >DEA,</a> y, al igual que el Cártel de Sinaloa, obtiene miles de millones de dólares de la producción de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2023/3/15/23641813/dea-sheila-lyons-fentanyl-sinaloa-cartel-jalisco-new-generation-drug-enforcement-administration" target="_blank" >fentanilo</a> y <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/2/24/23610152/methamphetamine-meth-fatal-overdoses-deaths-cook-county-drug-seizures-dea-adderall" target="_blank" >metanfetaminas</a>.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-3b0000" name="module-3b0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Un funcionario federal mexicano, que habló bajo condición de anonimato, dijo que la muerte de “El Mencho” ocurrió durante un operativo militar en el estado occidental de Jalisco y siguió a varias horas de bloqueos de carreteras con vehículos en llamas en Jalisco y otros estados. Tácticas como estas son comúnmente utilizadas por los cárteles de drogas de México para bloquear operativos militares.</p><p>Videos que circulan en redes sociales mostraron columnas de humo saliendo de Puerto Vallarta, una importante ciudad en Jalisco, y a personas corriendo aterrorizadas por el aeropuerto de la capital del estado.</p><p>El Departamento de Estado de Estados Unidos había ofrecido una recompensa de hasta $15 millones por información que llevara al arresto de “El Mencho”.</p><p>El Cártel Jalisco Nueva Generación (CJNC) es una de las organizaciones criminales más poderosas y de más rápido crecimiento en México.</p><p>En febrero, la administración de Trump designó al cártel como una organización terrorista extranjera.</p><p>Ha sido uno de los cárteles más agresivos en sus ataques contra el ejército —incluyendo helicópteros— y un pionero en el lanzamiento de explosivos desde drones e instalación de minas.</p><p>En 2020, llevó a cabo un espectacular intento de asesinato con granadas y rifles de alto poder en el corazón de la Ciudad de México contra el entonces jefe de la policía capitalina, que ahora es el encargado de la seguridad federal.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Fabiola Sanchez | AP

entries.title: 'Abolish ICE' among winners in Chicago's 'You Name a Snowplow' contest
entries.summary: <p>Chicago's snowplows will be named "Abolish ICE" and "Caleb Chilliams" after thousands cast votes in the city's "You Name a Snowplow" contest. </p><p>On Monday, the Department of Streets and Sanitation announced the six winning names for the fourth annual snowplow naming contest. They were pulled from more than 13,300 entries and 39,000 voters. </p><p>The top six snowplow names that received the most votes are "Abolish ICE," "Stephen Coldbert," "Pope Frío XIV," "The Blizzard of Oz," "Svencoolie" and "Caleb Chilliams."</p><p>"Chance the Scraper" received an honorable mention after it finished just .24% out of the top six, the news release said. </p><p>"I want to thank the people of Chicago for their unmatched creativity, sense of humor and civic pride," Mayor Brandon Johnson wrote in a news release. "We are grateful and inspired by the record-breaking participation in the contest this year." </p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: Greed is good on Wall Street but not in Billy Donovan's Bulls offense
entries.summary: <p>Billy Donovan knows the difference between need and greed.</p><p>Before becoming a Hall of Fame coach, it’s easy to forget that Donovan was one of the elite point guards in the country, guiding Providence to a memorable Final Four run. He then went from being a Friar to a buyer, spending almost five months as a stockbroker on Wall Street.</p><p>Two different worlds and hard lessons taught in both.</p><p>So while he admittedly never had the talent of a Rob Dillingham, he knows a little bit about when a point guard should be a buyer and when he should be a seller.</p><p>That’s why there have already been a handful of tough love moments since Dillingham has joined the Bulls in a trade deadline deal with Minnesota. The ultra quick guard has shown an ability to use his slick ball handling and wiggle to get into the teeth of the opposing defense, but has also put bad habits on display, trying to score from impossible angles once he does.</p><p>Bad habits that can be broken? That’s the hope.</p><p>“He is going to have to learn what gets you here doesn’t keep you here and what gets you here doesn’t necessarily take you to a next step,” Donovan said after the loss to the Knicks on Sunday. “As the talent gap shrinks, you have to make adjustments and changes. He’s so explosive and so fast with the ball, probably for most of his career no one could keep him in front. He probably got to the rim whenever he wanted to, and he could use his athleticism to go finish. Now all of a sudden he can’t do that all the time.”</p><p>Not that Dillingham didn’t have a few wow moments in his 24 minutes of work, scoring eight points, grabbing four rebounds and finishing a plus-9 in plus/minus when he was out there.</p><p>Yeah, the missed breakaway dunk wasn’t a shining moment, and he did force a few shots in the paint, but he also rallied a few minutes after that botched slam, drove the paint and sprayed it out to Patrick Williams for the three-pointer.</p><p>Textbook point guard play in Donovan’s offense.</p><p>And that’s the one issue the coach is having with Dillingham right now – decision making. Just because he could dominate the opposition in high school and college with blow-bys doesn’t mean he’ll get away with it in the Association.</p><p>Maybe that’s why Minnesota gave up on the No. 8 overall pick after just 84 regular-season games.</p><p>“What he can do at an elite level is get into the lane,” Donovan continued. “He’s got to make (better) decisions when he gets there. There’s balance where you don’t want to take away a guy’s aggressiveness by yanking him. He’s really gifted and talented and has great speed. This is going to be the evolution for him as a player, because with his size (he’s listed at 6-foot-2) there are certain things he can’t do at the basket. What he can do is make everyone else around him better, and that’s what we have to work with him on without taking away the aggressiveness.”</p><p>The good thing for Dillingham is more playing time might continue coming his way.</p><p>Anfernee Simons is sidelined with an injured wrist, Jaden Ivey might miss the remainder of the season as his knee is an issue, and Josh Giddey and Tre Jones remain on strict minutes restrictions.</p><p>A suddenly crowded guard room is down to Giddey, Jones, Collin Sexton and Dillingham, and in the Knicks game Dillingham played more than all three.</p><p>If he wants to continue that trend, he needs to understand one basic lesson from his coach: “Greed is good,” but only on Wall Street.</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson's death and plans to honor his life in Chicago
entries.summary: <p>The Rev. Jesse Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" target="_blank" >“died peacefully”</a> Feb. 17, his family said during a news conference last week. He was 84. </p><p>Jackson is a Chicago icon known for his work as a civil rights leader. "All are welcome" for services scheduled this week according to his family.</p><h3>When are services?</h3><p>Jackson will lie in state <b>Thursday, Feb. 26</b>, and <b>Friday, Feb. 27</b>, at Rainbow PUSH's Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m. </p><p>The service dates were adjusted Thursday after officials in South Carolina and Washington, D.C., offered to memorialize him there as well, so his remains will be traveling between March 1 and 5.</p><p>A "People's Celebration" in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. on <b>Friday, March 6</b>, at House of Hope at 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m.</p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. <b>Saturday, March 7</b>, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity. </p><p>Relatives of Jackson said that "all are welcome," regardless of political party.</p><p>"Do not bring your politics, out of respect to Rev. Jesse Jackson and the life that he lived, to these homegoing services. They come respectful and come to say thank you," Jesse Jackson Jr. said during a media event in front of the Jackson family home. "But these homegoing services are welcome to all — Democrat, Republican, liberal and conservative, right wing, left wing, because his life is broad enough to cover the full spectrum of what it means to be an American."</p><p>The family plans to livestream the services and will later share more information about how to watch from home. </p><h3>What hotels are recommended for those traveling in for the events?</h3><p>For those traveling to Chicago to attend services, they are encouraged to stay at the <b>Hyatt Regency McCormick Place Chicago</b> at 2233 S Martin Luther King Dr, according to the family's website. Rooms at the hotel have been reserved within a hotel block, with limited availability. </p><h3>Where can people expect to park?</h3><p>For those hoping to see Jackson lying in state events, street parking is available at Rainbow PUSH, along S Drexel Blvd, 49th St, E Hyde Park Blvd and E 49th St. </p><p>For the People's Celebration, parking will be available at House of Hope's parking lot along 113th St. </p><h3>What security measures will be in place?</h3><p>At each event, security checks and magnetometers will be in place. The family's website asks that individuals limit items brought to smooth the process. They prohibit weapons, signage and any items that could disrupt services. </p><p>For more information on the scheduled services visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.jessejacksonlegacy.com/" target="_blank" >jessejacksonlegacy.com</a>. </p><h3>Where will Jesse Jackson be buried?</h3><p>Jackson will be buried at <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2025/06/04/prejudice-follows-us-to-the-grave-the-segregated-past-of-chicago-cemeteries#:~:text=Mayor%20Harold%20Washington%20is%20buried,bring%20it%20to%20an%20end." target="_blank" >Oak Woods Cemetery</a>, the largest cemetery on the South Side, in Greater Grand Crossing. Chicago mayor Harold Washington, journalist and civil rights activist Ida B. Wells and Olympic athlete Jesse Owens are among those buried there.</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><h3>How did he die?</h3><p>While his family has not given an official cause of death nor said where he died, Jackson had been declining in health for a decade before his death. In 2015,<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" > Jackson was initially diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a>, but he revealed last April that he actually had progressive supranuclear palsy.</p><h3>How is the political world reacting to his death?</h3><p>Political figures from across the country have weighed in to pay their respects and honor his legacy. </p><p>In a joint statement, former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama wrote: "Michelle and I will always be grateful for Jesse's lifetime of service, and the friendship our families share. We stood on his shoulders. We send our deepest condolences to the Jackson family and everyone in Chicago and beyond who knew and loved him." </p><p>President Donald Trump also extended his sympathies to Jackson's family in a statement posted to Truth Social last week. </p><p>"I knew him well, long before becoming President," he said. "He was very gregarious — Someone who truly loved people! Despite the fact that I am falsely and consistently called a Racist by the Scoundrels and Lunatics on the Radical Left, Democrats ALL, it was always my pleasure to help Jesse along the way."</p><p>Chicago leaders, including Mayor Brandon Johnson and Gov. JB Pritzker, also shared their condolences. </p><p>"In honor of Rev. Jackson's service, and as our city mourns, the Chicago flag will lower to half-staff," Mayor Johnson wrote in a statement. </p><p>Pritzker also ordered all flags across the state to fly at half-mast to honor him in a statement posted on social media.</p><p>"He broke down barriers, inspired generations, and kept hope alive. Our state, nation, and world are better due to his years of service," Pritzker said.</p><h3>How are Chicago residents reacting to his death?</h3><p>Across the city, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-chicago-remembers" >Chicago residents mourned Jackson’s death</a> and urged that his legacy continue. </p><p>Martin Travis, a congregant of Apostolic Church of God in Woodlawn, said in his youth, his parents brought him to demonstrations organized by Operation Breadbasket, a group Jackson led. </p><p>Now, 64, Travis remembers Jackson as "instrumental in fighting for justice and freedom for all people."</p><p>Chloe Gould, 41, a Bronzeville resident, said that his death hit "like you lost a family member." </p><p>In the wake of his death, she said she worries about the future of civil rights activism, as activists and leaders have not stepped in to fill his shoes. </p><p>"Who is gonna be the civil rights activist now?" she asked. </p>
entries.author: Nicole Jeanine Johnson

entries.title: Cubs signing outfielder Michael Conforto to minor-league deal
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> are adding veteran outfielder Michael Conforto to spring training camp, bolstering their depth and adding a new wrinkle to the position battle.</p><p>The parties have agreed to a minor-league deal, sources confirmed Monday morning. After completing his physical, Conforto is expected to officially join team workouts on Tuesday.</p><p>“At this point, we're looking to bring in candidates to just strengthen the roster,” Cubs manager Craig Counsell said. “And it’s a sign of just continuing to do that. Michael had a down year last year, but has been a good player in this league for quite a while.”</p><p>Conforto, 32, hit just .199 with the Dodgers last season. But his decade-long career includes an All-Star nod in 2017, a 33-home run season in 2019, and .322 batting average and .927 OPS during the shortened 2020 season.</p><p>“He's a player that's had a lot of success in this league,” Counsell said. “And if he can recapture some of that, you’re going to have a useful player.</p><p>Conforto joins fellow non-roster invitee outfielders Dylan Carlson and Chas McCormick, all with proven major-league track records. The spring battle for the fourth outfield spot also includes Kevin Alcántara and Justin Dean, who are on the 40-man roster and have minor-league option years.</p><p>There will be plenty of available playing time for the group in the coming weeks, thanks to the World Baseball Classic. Right fielder Seiya Suzuki left Monday to join Team Japan in Tokyo. Center fielder Pete Crow-Armstrong is set to depart later this week to join Team USA. Both are expected to have deep runs in the tournament.</p><p>“Sometimes when you sign guys, it's like, where's the opportunity here?” Counsell said. “And then we show up in five days, and there's a big opportunity, right? So that's how you look at this.”<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Wiener's Circle Crossword Pop-Up
entries.summary: <p>What better way to celebrate Chicago’s birthday than with a free hot dog at Chicago’s finest, the Wiener’s Circle?</p><p>Find out if you’ve got that dog in you by completing the Sun-Times’ <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/games/chicago-mini-crossword" target="_blank" ><u>Chicago Mini Crossword</u></a> in under 90 seconds, while getting roasted by Wiener’s Circle staff.</p><p>If you do, you’ll win a free Chicago dog and relish in the glory of being a real wiener! 🌭</p><p><b>When: </b>Chicago's birthday! Wednesday,<b> </b>March 4 from 1-2:30 p.m. CT<br><b>Where:</b> The Wiener's Circle (<a class="Link" href="https://www.google.com/maps/place/The+Wiener's+Circle/@41.9301746,-87.6463591,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m6!3m5!1s0x880fd30ead7fd657:0xe1f21650c5953112!8m2!3d41.9301746!4d-87.6437788!16s%2Fm%2F04f5dbf?entry=ttu&g_ep=EgoyMDI2MDIxOC4wIKXMDSoASAFQAw%3D%3D" target="_blank" >2622 N Clark St</a>) </p><p>This event is free and open to the public.</p><p>Registration isn’t required, but you can RSVP to add to your calendar and get an email reminder <a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wieners-circle-crossword-pop-up-tickets-1983580800571?aff=Brightspot" target="_blank" >here</a>. </p><div class="ActionBox Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="ActionBox-content"> <div class="ActionBox-title">Wiener's Circle Crossword Pop-Up</div> <div class="ActionBox-description">March 4 from 1-2:30 p.m. </div> </div> <div class="ActionBox-cta"> <a class="Button" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wieners-circle-crossword-pop-up-tickets-1983580800571?aff=Brightspot" target="_blank" >RSVP</a> </div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: Death of Downers Grove man found on Austin street probed as homicide, police say
entries.summary: <p>The pre-dawn death of a 28-year-old Downers Grove man found on a West Side street is being investigated as a homicide, police said.</p><p>The victim, who name hasn’t been released by the Cook County medical examiner’s office, was found about 2:10 a.m. in the 5500 block of West Flournoy Street, police said.</p><p>He did suffer injuries, apparently to his head and body, but it was not clear what caused them, according to a source. An autopsy is scheduled.</p><p>The 28-year-old was taken to Mount Sinai Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.</p><p>Area 4 detectives are investigating.<br></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Chicago after the blitz
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: While federal immigration enforcement shrank when many agents left Chicago in November, the aftermath is affecting everyday life in Little Village, Pilsen and the Southeast Side.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: Parents protest a plan to close six Catholic schools, funeral services for Rev. Jesse Jackson begin and more news you need to know.</p><p>📝 <b>Keeping score</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-j/" target="_blank" >The Bulls fell to the class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-i/" target="_blank" >Fallout from Operation Midway Blitz continues in Latino neighborhoods</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-d/" target="_blank" >Araceli Gómez-Aldana</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-h/" target="_blank" >Michael Puente</a></h5><p><b>After the blitz</b>: The federal influx of some 300 agents for Operation Midway Blitz ended. But U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement activity continues. While it has remained at pre-Blitz levels, communities that the feds swarmed are changed. Here’s how things are different, according to people who live there.</p><p><b>Alejandra, a parent</b>: An immigrant from Mexico and a mother of three, Alejandra is worried for her children, one in high and two in elementary school in Pilsen. She says after the blitz, she's rethinking her children's involvement in extracurricular activities — and her own involvement in the community, with her sense of safety gone.</p><p><b>Cecy’s Molino de Masa</b>: Since 1986, Cecilia "Cecy" Villarruel has been producing masa in South Chicago. Since the blitz, Villarruel says there's been a decrease in sales, as people are afraid to wait in line — they'll send their grandchildren, or the business will make home deliveries. "People are terrorized to go out," Villarruel said.</p><p><b>Viento, the running club</b>: Before Operation Midway Blitz, the captains and runners of Viento, the Little Village run club, would only message each other to cancel a run. Now they message to check if there have been sightings of federal agents, then decide when they’ll run and their route. The club has a new rule: No one can run by themselves.</p><p><a class="Link" target="_blank" >More top arts organizations agree to share diversity data following survey</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-o/" target="_blank" >Erica Thompson</a></h5><p><b>DEI data</b>: New data provided by three major arts groups show increases in diversifying staff, boards and programs, though leaders say more needs to be done. The Joffrey Ballet, Chicago Architecture Center and Goodman Theatre agreed to share diversity data with WBEZ and the Sun-Times after initially declining or not responding to requests.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Last year, WBEZ/Sun-Times <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-b/" target="_blank" >surveyed the largest arts, culture and humanities nonprofits</a> about the diversity of their boards and full-time staff in 2021 and 2025. The intention was to measure progress five years after the murder of George Floyd. His death prompted many Chicago institutions to pledge to challenge racial discrimination and to add more people of color in staff and leadership roles. </p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-n/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>REV. Jesse Jackson’s life and legacy during a tribute at the headquarters of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition in Kenwood. The day marked the start of a slate of services for the Civil Rights giant, who died Tuesday at age 84.</p><p><b>Commemorations</b>: Services will continue as<a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-q/" target="_blank" > Jackson lies in repose</a> Thursday and Friday at Rainbow PUSH. His remains will then travel to South Carolina and Washington, March 1-5. A "People’s Celebration" in Chicago will be held 10 a.m. March 6 at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Private homegoing services are scheduled for March 7 at Rainbow PUSH.</p><p><b>Legacy look</b>: When Rev. Jackson arrived in Chicago in 1964, he faced a segregated system where Black and Latino students attempted to learn in schools so overcrowded that hallways became classrooms and supplies were scarce. He quickly jumped into the fight to end disparities in education — a cause he’d champion throughout his life. We take a look at <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-f/" target="_blank" >how he shaped Chicago education</a>.</p><p><a class="Link" Emil Jones III survived federal charges but now faces challengers in March primary</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-jr/" target="_blank" >Brett Chase</a></h5><p><b>Power of incumbency</b>: Despite previously facing federal charges, Illinois Sen. Emil Jones III (14th District) is endorsed by large labor groups, and he’s potentially on the verge of beating two opponents in a March primary. </p><p><b>Key context</b>: In April, it looked like Jones' political career was over. The South Side Democratic state senator, an officeholder since 2008, was on trial for federal charges of taking bribes and lying to federal authorities. Gov. Pritzker asked for his resignation. But after a mistrial, Jones in December announced an agreement with federal prosecutors that will keep him out of jail.</p><p><b>The challengers</b>: Newcomer Ahmed Karrar jumped into the race in January. Kenny Williams, who has previously run for other offices, is also challenging Jones.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-jy/" target="_blank" ><b>READ target="_blank" >Irving Park studio gets visitors to ‘slow down’ by spinning wool into yarn</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-ty/" target="_blank" >Mariah Rush</a></h5><p>Since opening in November, a 600-square-foot space in Irving Park has been home to people looking to slow down thanks to wooden tools used to spin raw wool into yarn.</p><p>Inclement Craft, 3436 W. Irving Park Road, is a fine fiber retailer and studio space that has created its own community ranging from experienced spinners and fiber artists to those curious about working with yarn. The studio hosts classes and events like Handspinning 101 and indigo dye parties.</p><p>The fiber arts have gained popularity particularly after the pandemic, as the trend of an <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-tj/" target="_blank" >analog life</a> — less phones and more human experiences — gains traction this year.</p><p>For those looking to unplug, spinning and the fiber arts are a welcoming hobby, Inclement Craft owners Aaron Storm and Nathaniel Millard said.</p><p>"There’s not a numerical element. You’re not counting," Storm said. "It gets to be a little more mindful."</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-tt/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p> </p><h4>WATCH: INSIDE INCLEMENT </div></div><hr><p></p><h4>YOUR DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><p>On Friday, we asked you: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjjrc-l-th/" target="_blank" ><b>How serious do you think the Bears are about going to Indiana?</b></a></p><p>Here’s some of what you said, edited for clarity and space:</p><p>"I'll believe it when they get rid of the NFL's best fight song, containing the line 'the pride and joy of Illinois,' which also pays homage to their origin in Decatur." — <i>Roger Deschner</i></p><p>"Those money-grubbers are very serious about Indiana — until Illinois proposes a better deal than the Hoosiers. Then they will be 'so focused' on staying in Illinois until Indiana proposes [another deal]." — <i>Kevin Beese</i></p><p>"The Bears will follow the money and go to Indiana if the Hoosiers are the high bidder ... I will not go to the new stadium because I do not give my money to blackmailers." — <i>Doug Berman</i></p><p>"About 25% serious. They'd be getting an amazing deal, but even a franchise this historically poorly run is probably concerned about the optics of leaving the state of Illinois. They're using it as leverage, looking to squeeze out every last bit of tax breaks they can in Illinois." — <i>Jordan Mainzer</i></p><p>"I don't think it matters if the Bears are serious about this move or that. What matters is whether or not the owners are willing to invest in a team that has made them billionaires, and it is clear they are not. Instead, they want the public to pay for it ." — <i>Bill McCormick</i></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ii/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>

entries.title: Realizan funeral de adolescente de Chicago con cáncer que luchó por la liberación de su padre
entries.summary: <p>El Ford Mustang azul que le regaló su padre a Ofelia Giselle Torres Hidalgo ayudó a escoltar el ataúd marfil de la joven de 16 años a la Parroquia de San William el viernes por la mañana en el vecindario de Montclare del lado noroeste.</p><p>Docenas de dolientes se abrazaron mientras salían de la misa fúnebre privada en la fría y nublada mañana, mientras sonaban las campanas de la iglesia.</p><p>El padre Ryszard Gron, quien dio la homilía fúnebre, les dijo a los reporteros afuera de la iglesia que su comunidad tenía “suerte de acompañar a la familia de Ofelia”.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-660000" name="module-660000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Nuestra vida futura [siempre estará basada] en lo que hacemos aquí”, dijo Gron. “Ella será feliz ahora, y es feliz ahora en las manos de Dios”.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> febrero tras luchar contra un rabdomiosarcoma alveolar metastásico, una forma rara y agresiva de cáncer de tejidos blandos.</p><p>El año pasado, comenzó quimioterapia después de que el cáncer avanzara a la etapa 4. En octubre, un día después de ser dada de alta el fin de semana del Lurie Children’s Hospital para ver a familiares y amigos, su padre, Rubén Torres Maldonado, fue detenido por agentes del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE) en Niles.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://www.suntimeswire.com/2025/10/25/ruben-torres-maldonado-daughter-battling-cancer-judge-ruling" target="_blank" ><u>Los médicos dijeron</u></a> que ella no podía continuar con el tratamiento “debido al estrés y la interrupción” causados por el arresto.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div
